Noah, formerly Consul at Tunis and now Editor of the National Advocate a Newspaper at New-York; a Jew of considerable talents, but whose conduct was so indiscreet that he was recalled from his Consulate, and not long since published a book to vindicate himself, and assail the President— He now asks an appointment as Charge d’Affaires at Vienna or elsewhere; with which he connects a plan for bringing Settlements of wealthy Jews to this Country— This evening was again rainy, but with the weather so sultry that I could not read by candle-light.

30. IV:30. We all attended Church at Mr M’Cormick’s. He read prayers for the 9th. Sunday after Trinity, and gave notice that he should administer the communion next Sunday— His Sermon was from Luke XVIII. from the tenth to the thirteenth verse inclusive, being the Parable of the Pharisee and the Publican— And the doctrine which he drew from it was an exhortation to humility. After an exordium, remarking upon the earnestness with which this quality is recommended in the Scriptures generally, he divided his subject into a comparative view of the conduct of the Pharisee and the Publican— He noticed the Pride, the self-sufficiency, the vain-boasting of the former, and observed how inconsistent it was with the Spirit of Prayer— How unsuitable to a being whose very act of going to the temple to pray implied a condition of dependence and of want. He contrasted this with the humble and contrite exclamation of the publican, which he recommended to the imitation of his hearers, concluding with a solemn admonition to them all, that there was not among them one but who on faithfully and rigidly scrutinizing his own heart and conduct would find himself called to say with the Publican, God be merciful to me a Sinner.— This was an ordinary Sermon, in which the topics of spiritual arrogance, and self abasement were handled in an obvious manner— But the Sermon of Sterne upon this Parable, has left scarcely any thing else to be said by others. The great and peculiar foundation of the Christian system of morals is the union of humility and benevolence— Every man must consider himself as a sinner towards God; as always needing and never capable of deserving mercy— The Pharisee was fully sensible of all this as applicable to others— He was sensible too that every good and perfect gift was from god— He thanks God for his Virtues, which all consist in the observance of the positive Law— He does no wrong— But his active virtue is all confined to fasting and paying tithes. The publican is painted—standing afar off—not daring even to raise his eyes—but smiting his breast—every incident heightens the image of sincere and profound humility— It is not intimated that there was any falsehood in the words of the Pharisee—it is implied that the sins of the publican were greater than those of the Pharisee—the lesson was to those who trusted in themselves that they were righteous and despised others. The doctrine is that the repentance of a Sinner justifies him before God more than the self-confiding virtue of the righteous— The Pharisees were rigid observers of the Letter of the Law; but their leaven was hypocrisy. The Pharisees were in high repute for their sanctity, and had an overruling influence among the People. The publicans were the taxgatherers for the Romans; universally detested, and every where admitted throughout the gospels to be vicious. Christ call was for repentance and he came to seek and to save that which was lost— It has been objected by some modern speculators in moral philosophy, that the Christian doctrine lays too much stress upon this virtue of humility: that by assuming as a principle that man is a fallen and degraded being, utterly incapable of himself, either of doing any good or of redeeming himself from the destruction which he has incurred it makes him a coward and a hypocrite—that it gives him the appearance in prayer of a recreant slave before an incensed and tyrannical master— That the doctrine of the Stoics which rested upon an exalted estimate of human nature and human powers, which supposed the will of man to be above all evil physical or moral was a sounder basis of ethics than that of Christ— There is weight in these remarks; but the natural passions of man are so selfish, and his feeling for others, excepting his own offspring is so
weak that they require a counteracting check of positive precept to restore the balance— The tendencies of the Stoical doctrine, and indeed those of all the Grecian Sects of Philosophy were all selfish— The end of their enquiry was Happiness—the Supreme Good—Enjoyment— Epicurus found it in pleasure— Zeno, in virtue— The end of the Christian, and before it of the Jewish doctrine was not happiness, but duty— No enquiry for the Summum bonum— Man is told that he was created with it, that his first forefather lost it by disobedience—that the capacity to recover it was secured to him by the atonement of Christ’s Death; and that he must complete the recovery by repentance, by obedience and by doing good to others. The Christian system therefore is in all its tendencies eminently social— The end of its enquiries, is the happiness of others. After returning home, I read the Chapter, of the text, and Hewlett’s commentary upon it— Wrote to my Son George; and read Shenstone’s Choice of Hercules— It is much inferior to Spence’s version of the same Fable in Stanza’s— The ideas are all diluted, the images indistinct— The Portraits of the two Ladies, are coarsely drawn; the voluptuousness of the one is without fascination, and the severity of the other without dignity— I spent the Evening at Mr Calhoun’s— The day was showery with thunder and lightening.

31. V: The morning was swallowed up by this Journal. At the Office I found a Captain William Low, Master of a Schooner belonging to Baltimore, from whom Admiral Brion and Colonel Mariano Montilla last May, took by force, between five and six hundred barrels of flour, for which Montilla gave him as order upon the Treasury of the Republic of Colombia at Angostura— Low is now going there in a vessel from Baltimore, to sail in the course of this week, directly for Angostura; and he came to ask for any aid which the Government can furnish him. I promised him Letters for C. S. Todd and Dr Forsyth for which he is to call to-morrow. I took this opportunity to answer the Letters received from both of them, and also to write one to Forsyth Todd instructing him to remonstrate against the pretended admiralty Court at the Island of Margaritta, and against the countenance given to the piratical privateers by it—and especially to demand the revocation of Almeida’s Commission—the Restitution of the vessel which he took in our waters, and the money plundered from it, belonging to Citizens of the United States. This employed all my Office hours, and left much current business to be postponed. Mrs W. S. Smith was here after dinner. Evening Showery, with thunder.

Day. The range of my rising hour through the Month has been from four to half past five; and the average, five about half the days, I borrow an hour and a half before breakfast to bathe in the river. The rest of the time, I am writing the Journal of the preceding day and sometimes ten days of the old index. We usually breakfast from nine to ten— Seldom interrupted now by visitors at my house, it is yet Noon or later before I leave it to walk to my Office—the distance is just a mile. Some of the hottest days I ride to it in the Carriage; but scarcely ever, except after having walked to the river— I remain at the Office till five or later, occupied with the current business, writing, and looking occasionally into Newspapers— Between five and six I walk or ride home and immediately dine. After dinner, while day-light lasts I read the Newspapers, but from the dusk of Evening, pass an hour or two of total vacancy, sitting at the porch of the door, or the chamber window; almost gasping for breath and maintaining the war with Spiders, bugs and musquitoes— Between nine and ten I usually retire to bed; and sleep with open windows— The morning from the time of rising till breakfast is the delightful part of the day; the heat being then supportable, and employment turning it to enjoyment. The Evening on the other hand is irksome—sultry; peopled with noisome insects, calm, breathless, and worst of all, idle— The Newspapers absorb too many hours, and mere nothingness, trifles of which I can give no account even to myself, many more. The consciousness of duty unperformed is ever present with me.
